>>91370401
It really depends on what you're looking for in a Linux distribution. Both Artix and VoidLinux have their own unique strengths and weaknesses.

Artix is known for being a user-friendly distro that uses OpenRC as its init system instead of Systemd, which is a popular choice among those who value simplicity and stability.

VoidLinux, on the other hand, is known for its rolling release model, which means you always have access to the latest software and updates. It also uses the XBPS package manager, which is fast and efficient.

In the end, it all comes down to personal preference. You should try both of them out and see which one you like better.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91367087
Systemd was originally designed to replace sysvinit (PID 1) of linux systems, as an init system. It's meant to boot a Linux system up. Now it's capable of:
> full networking
> address resolution
> daemons - system, and user level
> pipes - system and user
> filesystem init (folder structure on tmpfs)
> mounts
> pseudovirtualization (see: docker)
> cron

It needs to die because it's cancer, and it's rapidly growing. Not because it's a spyware.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's GPT-3 and most likely finetuned GPT-3.

GPT-3 is much more powerful than ChatGPT. ChatGPT is based on GPT-3. There is API for GPT-3 and you can do way more stuff on it than in the ChatGPT. It's not free though.

It's approximately 2 cents per 750 words (it's more complicated than that). And it's calculated twice, the input and the output. So if you Give it 375 words as input and the model outputs 375 words as "answer", then it costs you 2 cents.
Then there is the "fine tune" models where you can create your own fine tunes of the GPT-3 and that shit is very powerful. It costs you 6 times more per token than the normal one.

If this reply was from finetuned GPT-3 model, the response would have cost you 2,25 cents.

Its basically a Unity game connected to a GPT-3. It just loops between room and mic stand with the building transition inbetween, when on a room (There is 2, Larry and Fred's rooms) it spawns a random number of characters between 2 and 4, these characters just interact with props (couches, microwave, fridge, sink) regardless of their dialog. When on the mic set is just spawns Larry on a fixed camera angle and no movement

Fun fact, the script that setups procedurally generated music can conflict with the load order of all scripts, usually if the music generation wins the race condition it fails to spawn Larry altogether on the mic set, if Larry spawn/setup wins there is no procedural music other than the background beat which is fixed for the mic scenes

posts.com:
high availability of /hsg/ thread cluster edition

READ THE WIKI! & help by contributing:
https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki/Home_server

>NAS Case Guide. Feel free to add to it:
https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki/Home_server/Case_guide

/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. Know all about NAS? Learn virtualization. Spun up some VMs? Learn about networking by standing up a OPNsense/PFsense box and configuring some VLANs. There's always more to learn and chances to grow. Think you’re god-tier already? Setup OpenStack and report back.

>What software should I run?
Install Gentoo. Or whatever flavour of *nix is best for the job or most comfy for you. Jellyfin/Plex to replace Netflix, Nextcloud to replace Googlel, Ampache/Navidrome to replace Spotify, the list goes on. Look at the awesome self-hosted list and ask.

>Why should I have a home server?
/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. De-botnet your life. Learn something new. Serving applications to yourself, your family, and your frens feels good. Put your tech skills to good use for yourself and those close to you. Store their data with proper availability redundancy and backups and serve it back to them with a /comfy/ easy to use interface.

Server tips: https://anonbin.io/?1759c178f98f6135#CzLuPx4s2P7zuExQBVv5XeDkzQSDeVkZMWVhuecemeN6

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91337345
Prometheus works by scraping configured targets for metrics. This is all done over HTTP so you can actually open the metrics endpoints in a browser and see what is being done.
You'll want to install prometheus-node-exporter on any server that you want to collect metrics from. Node exporter will collect metrics from the system and then make them available on port 9100, which will be queried by your prometheus server.
The prometheus configuration file on the prometheus server defines what targets to scrape. So it would look something like this:
scrape_configs:
  - job_name: servers
    static_configs:
      - targets: [
        servera:9100,
        serverb:9100,
        serverc:9100
      ]


The second part of the setup is to get prometheus data into grafana where you can graph the data for ease of monitoring. This part isn't too hard, just follow the documentation for adding a prometheus data source into grafana.
And once you've setup the prometheus data source you'll want to setup a dashboard in grafana for viewing the data.
Grafana has a community dashboards page where you can find pre-built dashboards and import them into grafana. There's one called "Node Exporter Full" which is exactly what you'll be looking for. Just import that dashboard into grafana and then you'll be able to view all of your metrics.

>>91338245
>thanks, i managed to import Node Exporter Full and see the metrics of my prometheus server container, there's too many stats though i will need to find a simpler dashboard.
Use the panels in that dashboard as a template to make your own custom dashboard. No need to reinvent the wheel when you can just copy some of the pre-built panels.
>i'll also have to install the exporter on my router so i can monitor it.
>i looked around it seems there are also snmp exporters and similar, i would like to scan and display information about hosts connected to my network, something like nmap would do, i'll google a bit.
What you're looking for here is the blackbox exporter or possibly the SNMP exporter as you mentioned. The blackbox exporter will attempt to connect to a target with a specific protocol and return the results,
For example, I use the blackbox exporter to make SMTP and IMAP connections to monitor my mail server and also HTTP(S) connections to my various web services.
The SNMP exporter works much the same way.
>anyway this is all isolated to my local network, but is it safe to just expose all metrics from hosts like that?
You can setup authentication which I would definitely recommend for a public instance, but for a private network setting up firewall rules to only allow traffic to the metrics endpoints from your prometheus server should suffice.

>>91332719
Constant sync of drives isn't a backup, it's closer to RAID1. That only saves you if one of drives fails, doesn't save you if you accidentally delete a song. I'd use the other drive in a USB enclosure, maybe write a small script to rsync data as soon as it's plugged in. Syncthing is pretty nice for sync of files from phones, I use Syncthing-Fork on family Android devices.
As for your future server, you certainly don't need a rack right away. TrueNAS Scale is a bit imperfect choice for home imo because devs wanted it to be a building block of HCI infrastructure (compute+storage) for enterprise, so the way you run Docker containers there is via Kubernetes. For a home use where there's just one server usually, K8s adds pointless complexity. Seems pretty decent otherwise.
OMV is less polished imo, but I don't want to pick on anything that I haven't tested myself.

>>91335502
Call the support and ask them for switching it into bridge for you, or to give you a public/static IP. If they refuse you can try to abuse their router to get admin privileges on it (unplug from network, reset to defaults via physical button, login with defaults, poke around and connect to their network), or do other stuff like UPnP. Good reason for static IP is work requirements, often you have some servers whitelist specific IPs to login via SSH for example.
Wireguard server still needs a forwarded port. You could try running it on VPS and using it as gateway into your selfhosted stuff, or try Zerotier or Tailscale+Headscale.

>>91345958
Those enclosures have a vendor lock and won't detect drives not made by WD. There was a guide somewhere online that told which pin you can cut off from a (iirc) 6 pin chip to disable it and let enclosure work with other drives as well.
>>91345983
Arch is pretty okay for a server you connect to regularly and give it gentle htop scrubs and neofetch runs. I like it, I haven't had any very notable issues compared to Debian (well, something was a bit broken after an update but I forgot what, it was fixable). Just consider using 
checkservices
to restart services using old libraries and check configs that were updated by pacman. 
kernel-modules-hook
is a very useful pacman hook that will save modules for currently running kernel during its package updates - so you can keep server running for a while on old kernel, and be able to insert modules e.g. for USB storage a week later without reboot. These are my essential tips for using Arch on home server. docker-compose to run services in a portable and isolated manner, zfs-utils and zfs-dkms from AUR to have the nice filesystem, and it's pretty comfy.
Usually I don't recommend TrueNAS etc. because if you are comfortable with Linux and CLI, you'll get best setup for yourself if you setup it, well, yourself.
I was about to suggest you sell 1080 if you don't need HEVC transcoding, but this CPU is Broadwell despite 6 in model number and doesn't have iGPU, huh. So maybe you'll want to look into nvidia-patch on GitHub to unlock concurrent transcodes limit. Arch will make it a bit annoying with frequent Nvidia driver updates, but you can always wait a bit with upgrading if needed.

>>91351700
>what i don't understand yet is how to have multiple hosts under the same dashboard.
Look at how Node Exporter Full dashboard does it - on top you'll have a drop-down box with available hosts to show data from. You can make panels which show data from multiple hosts at once, or have two panels side by side showing metrics from each host. Look how the premade dashboards were made, you can edit them via GUI.
>a single dashboard so i understand what is going on in my lan at a glance
I think I would go with Prometheus, Grafana and Loki and a mix of Prometheus exporters for all of those devices to achieve that. Grafana will let you have single pane observability that way, although for now I think ELK is a bit nicer for logs (the search/filter and instant indexing is gold), but you'd have Grafana for metrics and Kibana for logs. Kibana can also show metrics stored in Elastic but that sounds a bit over engineered.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91363376
>How do I know if programs can run commands via SSH?
ssh is how you connect to the server (the actual computer) from whence you can run any of the same commands you could run if you were sitting in front of the computer. there is no "this application can be run through ssh" because ssh is just an alternative to plugging your keyboard into the box itself.

pretty much everything and anything can be done through the COMMAND LINE which is what you are using when you connect via ssh. in fact, almost every if not all installation doccumentation for server applications such as docker, jellyfin, bittorrent client (you want transmission or deluge, qbittorrent does not have a HEADLESS (aka, command line only) version that is suitable), and so on.
you want to become familiar with the command line. it isn't difficult, even if it seems scary. the reason you want headless server applications as opposed to a clickable gui, is that headless "daemons" as they are called are actually significantly LESS complicated to work with and easier to use and configure, it just takrs a little bit of learning which commands do what. but theres like five or six commands at most that you actually need to know, like nano (text editor), systemctl (manages what daemons are running) and apt (for installing programs/commands).

most of the programs you mentioned habe very good and clear guides for installation, eg for deluge (a bittorrent client) it's as simple as
>apt install deluged deluge-web
>systemctl enable --now deluged
a VPN is a bit more complex to set up and depends on your provider, but you will be using a tool called openVPN to connect to expressVPN's servers, again this is fairly simple but theres a few steps required that are specific to your VPN company and location.

and there are guides for EVERYTHING you could possibly do on a server, so don't worry.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
What I/O scheduler is everyone using for their RAID drives? I knew for years that my array was slow while a scan was running, but this was not a problem worth dealing with because the drives were small enough for the scan to complete overnight.

I have since made another array with much larger 16TB drives and a scan nigh-on takes a full 24h, so feeling the slowness is now inevitable. I did a bit a reading to solve this, long story short I found that the Debian checkarray script DOES attempt to run the scan "idle" priority, which should not interfere with higher priority I/O (that) much, but this did not seem to work at all. I barely got over 10MB/s sequential read from the array while it was being scanned. Turns out this was happening because the I/O scheduler used by default (mq-deadline) actually has no support for I/O priorities at all.

I ended up switching to "bfq" which seems to work wonders, I get like 250MB/s while the scan is running now, which is more than fine. Is this the right way to deal with this shit? Is bfq the right I/O scheduler to use? It seems to me there's surprisingly little information about this available, I basically pieced this solution together myself, haven't found any actual recommendation on how to deal with this anywhere.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91367160
everything you're saying is also true of a CLI, so I don't really understand where you're coming from

the arguments in favor of a GUI would be that you don't have to worry about typos or exact syntax, but "leaving more complex stuff for later" has nothing to do with your user interface and everything to do with what you are being taught. Almost every learning resource for CLI will teach you only very basic things first and not inundate you with complex stuff.

Take for example routerOS (because I have recently started teaching this). heres your GUI - now find how to add a new port forwarding rule from that
vs with the CLI, and if you look up any guide for it, it's as simple as
>add action dst-nat src-ip 192.168.0.69 blah blah
explaining to someone the details of a CLI command not only is much easier than "look for the dropdown menu and then the next dropdown which is somewhere on the right of the screen and then back in the middle click the next button", you can also help people learn what each step means and does in a very succinct, easy-to-understand manor.
Trying to explain what any given page of a GUI does with it's millions of buttons can become tedious and confuse people. Every time I get new students to open something like aa cisco switch manager I see looks of horror on their faces (granted, cisco has terrible UIs) vs breaking down a few common commands, which not only helps them get started faster, they also understand what they are doing much earlier and better than doing it through the GUI.

just compare "systemctl status foobar" to window's service manager and you'll understand why GUI is not always easier or better

In the 90s they had these things called expert systems. Just a fancy name for gigantic databases of if-then-else statements in a huge database.
>If pt has a high heart rate
>Check blood pressure
>If blood pressure is high
>Check urine for catecholamines
>If catecholamines are high
>Run PET scan with and without contrast
>...etc etc
Even back then, that is 30 years ago, these expert systems, just using published standards of care, could diagnose a patient correctly about 87% of the time. A human doctor would only get it right about 65% of the time.

So your question is can the AI diagnose human conditions? Fucking of course they can.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91370231
Okay nvm about that. Here's my thoughts on the cases:
>Be Quiet Pure Base 500DX
Good case. Especially at the reduced ~€110 price point. IMO the aesthetics are better than most but the lack of a solid panel option, or even heavily tinted glass, is a detractor.
>Fractal Design Meshify 2 Compact
This is the best one of the bunch by my standards but is a bit small for current high-end cards. The full size version is often quite expensive but makes sense if the budget is higher.
>Cooler master Masterbox NR600 (or 400)
I'm not too familiar with this one. It looks okay but I don't see much reason take it over those above unless the price is very good.
>Corsair 275R Airflow
This was great when it was one of the few <€80 "airflow" cases. Now the market is more saturated there's better options in terms of thermals. Worth considering if the budget is tight and you can still find it for €70.
>Corsair Carbide 4000D
The "Airflow" model is the one to get. By all accounts it's an excellent case. Has proper filtration, good build, and looks slick (rice window aside). It does lack in fans so, if you don't have any spare, add another €10 to the price when comparing.

On the whole all of these cases are at least "decent" - so long as everything fits I expect you'd be satisfied with the performance of any of them. If you're really in doubt pick the one you like the looks of most.

not just with computers, this applies to everything technological - korzybski's "time binding"
each generation builds upon the work of the previous, nobody really fully understanding or appreciating the previous levels. there will be some old timers at retirement age who have a bunch of stories to tell but probably nobody cares by that point

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91355910
>iPhone almost 60% faster than z fold 4 *on paper* but literally loads websites slower?
"faster" is an industry term and doesn't really correlate to real-world benchmarks, but you're not totally wrong;

>literally loads websites slower
iOS applications are built and shipped at higher-level than android apps (which should really be called "programs"). So it typically (not always) takes more computation, even on a faster processor, to get the same work done.

>loads websites
a lot of this is to do with your wifi and cellular radio, not the device's computing performance. The larger device almost certainly has longer and more sensitive antennas, that's just geometry. They can also be spaced further apart (bluetooth and wifi sometimes interfere) from each other and the other noisy components.

What was it about personal computers that started feeling rather sterile in the mid to late 2010s? Up until that point since the 1980's it felt as though everything was almost always getting better no matter what and that there was always the intention of showing off just how these machines can be used and what they can do with an assortment of neat aesthetics. The Windows 7 era kind of felt like the last major leap forward on all fronts into the future, and that it couldn't get much better than that. I suppose the same could be said about the world in general, but even then if you still stuck to the same stuff you had in your corner of the world (regardless if the rest of the world moved on) you could have kept that theoretically kept some of that experience going by preserving the same overall environment.

int count_anagrams(std::string_view all_words, std::string_view ref_word)
{
  int reference_sum = std::accumulate(ref_word.begin(), ref_word.end(), (int)0); 
  int res =  0;
  for (const auto& word : std::views::split(all_words, " "))
    {
      int sum = std::accumulate(word.begin(), word.end(), 0);
      res += (sum == reference_sum) ? 1 : 0;
    }
  return res;
}

#![allow(unused)]
fn is_anagram(arg1: &str, arg2: &str) -> bool {
    let mut arg1 = arg1.as_bytes().to_vec();
    arg1.sort();
    let mut arg2 = arg2.as_bytes().to_vec();
    arg2.sort();
    arg1 == arg2
}

fn anime_is_for_trannies(all_words: &[&str], waifu_name: &str) -> usize {
    all_words
    .iter()
    .filter(|w| is_anagram(w, waifu_name))
    .count()
}

auto waifuAnas(std::vector<std::string_view> s, std::string_view w) -> int {
  int count{};
  std::unordered_map<char, int> wmp{};
  for(auto i: w) {
    wmp[i]++;
  }
  for(auto i: s) {
    if(i.size() != w.size()) continue;
    std::unordered_map<char, int> tmp{};
    for(auto j: i) {
      tmp[j]++;
    }
    if(tmp == wmp) count++;
  }
  return count;
}

>Rest api
>Nestjs for monolith backend
>Golang (or rust?) for tracker decoding service
Don't use Rust unless you're already experienced with it in this domain. Plus it's better to only drop down to systems langs when you hit a dead end performance-wise with JS, Go, etc.
Also, why not just use Go entirely? If you're planning on fragmenting the monolith into separate services over time then I'd just start by writing the monolith in Go and breaking pieces out of it over time rather than starting with a JS framework and a Go service.
Everything else is fine, but personally I prefer React-based frameworks over Vue. Also, if you're going to use a cloud provider for hosting you might want to go with their implementation over handling RabbitMQ manually, but neither choice is wrong in that situation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91360667
Break problem into small pieces, research and develop.

Real life example that happened to me:
Client wants an application to collect data of highway road quality (asphalt, dranage, sinalization, etc)

Talk with client to determine what exactly he needs to collect
Talk with client to determine other requirements (must work offline? Is it only local? Etc)
Get overview of the whole system
Break it into pieces (frontend, backend)
Keep breaking (eg: backend into task backlog)
Describe what each piece is suppossed to do (eg: login functionality)
If needed keep breaking the task until its so simple you can imagine a solution in pseudocode or a simple flow (eg: request comes in with creds, search db for user with email and hashed password, success if found, unauthorized if not)
Do this for your whole peoblem

I think Im missing something about NextJS nested routing.
Assuming I have a few pages, each one of them with a subfolder [field] for a dynamic path value.
The path is on the form of "/pagex/myvar?field2=myvar2"
Literally all these Links work the same:
        <Link href="/page2/[field]" as={'/page2/myvar'}>
          <div className="test">Go to Page 2 (path)</div>
        </Link>
        <Link href="/page3/[field]?field2=myvar2" as={`/page3/${field1}`}>
          <div className="test">Go to Page 3 (path+query)</div>
        </Link>
        <Link href="/page4/myvar?field2=myvar2">
          <div className="test">Go to Page 4 (path+query without alias)</div>
        </Link>
        <Link href={`/page5/${field1}?field2=${field2}`}>
          <div className="test">Go to Page 5 (path+query without alias and string literal)</div>
        </Link>

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91367298

set video.preservesPitch to false

// ==UserScript==
// @name         AV-Man
// @version      N/A
// @description  N/A
// @author       Anonymous
// @match        *://*/*
// @grant metadata
// ==/UserScript==
document.addEventListener('keydown', function (event) {
  const tagName = event.target.tagName.toLowerCase();
  if (tagName === 'textarea' || tagName === 'input') {
    return;
  }
  const videos = document.querySelectorAll('video');
  for (const video of videos) {
    video.preservesPitch = false;
    switch (event.key) {
      case ']':
        video.playbackRate *= 1.059463094352953;
        break;
      case '[':
        video.playbackRate *= 0.9438743126816935;
        break;
      case '\\':
        video.playbackRate = 1;
        break; /* WIP *
          case 76: // (l)
              video.currentTime  += 5 ;
              break ;
          case 72: // (h)
              video.currentTime  -= 5 ;
              break ;                   * WIP */
    }
  }
});

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91369996
Add a second resource record with name field empty, type A, TTL 600, Public IP = your VPS IP address.
Add a third resource record with a single asterisk * in the name field, type A, TTL 600, Public IP = your VPS IP address.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91370151
If you've followed your pic it should have worked only if you pinged www.<your_domain>.<your_tld>
The second record will allow to ping <your_domain>.<your_tld> without www.
The third record will allow to ping any sub domain, examples myservice1.<your_domain>.<your_tld>, myservice2.<your_domain>.<your_tld>.

In theory, you can remove your first record, the one with name field www, because the * will catch it for you anyway.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91363425
>soundstage doesn't exist
Correct, why do you have such trouble understanding this? Speakers localize outside your head because the crosstalk gives the distance from the source and literally create a soundstage that isn't recording dependent. It doesn't matter what you listen to, it will sound outside your head and three-dimensional. Headphones and IEMs cannot do the same, there is no "soundstage" that isn't inherent to the recording, like binaural audio that is a close match in HRTF. If it's not created by the device itself by definition it's not soundstage so you can fuck off with your meme buzzword.
>b-b-b-but how come I have IEMs that sound more open
Because that is an unrelated property that is FR dependent. Go from hard hitting bass to no bass, it will sound more open but still be in your head.

posts.sub: /aosg/&/aig/ - Alternative ISA General/Alternative Operating System General (Combined)
posts.com:
ITT, we discuss alternative operating systems and alternative ISA.

We discuss alternatives to Windows, Mac and Linux, such as SerenityOS, Haiku, GNU/HURD, AmigaOS/AROS and rare BSDs, as well homebrew projects and operating system development.
We also we discuss non-x86 ISAs from the past (6502, 68000, Alpha, Itanium, PA-RISC, PowerPC, SuperH, VAX, Z80, PDP-11), the present (ARM, MIPS, POWER, SPARC) and the future (RISC-V, OpenPOWER).

You can also ask here for more information. Don't forget to check out the wiki, by the way!

>AIG Wiki: https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki//aig/_Alternative_ISA_General
>AOSG wiki: https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki//aosg/_Alternative_Operating_System_General

Previous /aig/|/aosg/: >>91289845

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91336795
This is why I am not writing one. I started my 2nd attempt at an operating system on the first of January as my new year's resolution. 6 years ago I started wrting an OS and the community I went to chat with others doing the same urged me to write a comprehensive bootloader, to support both BIOS boot and UEFI, and to test it on real hardware. Turned out to be a horrid combination of simple but tedious. I gave up because it was so damned boring.
It's not even like it was for any gain - the bootloader runs once then fucks off. So the "but this way it's only MY code running on the machnie" doesn't hold water, because the bootloader fucks off. It's an even more invalid point because the system firmware also ran, so it's NOT only 'your own code' running, and in fact the system firmware sticks around too.
So this time around I made the decision to get straight to work on what I was actually interested in - the scheduler, synchronization, and IPC. I've built multilevel feedback queue with three priority classes - one for interrupts, one for realtime, and one for normal processes, each with 32 priority levels. Almost all hardware interrupts are handled by a special kind of lightweight kernel thread I've called a threadlet, which simplifies coding dramatically - mutexes, semaphores, monitors, and message queues are available for synchronizing everywhere. I have mitigated priority inversion through a system of propagated priority inheritance, which is essential since interrupt threads use these high-level synchronization mechanisms instead of relying on spinlocks.
And I completely ignored people who said I need to write a bootloader. I found a simple bootloader called bootboot which puts you straight into x86_64 mode so you don't need to fuck with decades of legacy bullshit in modern PCs. Now I've got something I feel proud of already. I can't wait to make it better.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91349518
>>super portable microkernel OS
Sure, many exist. The FAQ lists quite a few.
>>Boot it on your CPU
Sure, this is trivial, and again many are listed in the FAQ.
>>Boot it on your GPU
Herein lies the problem. the GPU is typically an array of poorly documented processors that are very good at calculations and tight loops, but very poor at branching.
>>Treat them like separate networked computers and your boot drive like a SAN
There is little stopping you (perhaps other than poor documentation), but don't let that stop you from trying. Lots of big tasks would never have been completed, not even started, had people known in advance how much hard work it would have involved.

It might be simpler/better if you made the CPU and GPU yourself, perhaps based on existing designs. That way documenttaion is not a problem and you can even optimise the GPu design for this very purpose.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91356070
That depends on the algorithm and the initial state of the array. If you assume that the array is a completely random configuration, then the likelihood of the array being sorted in any arbitrary number of steps before the algorithm terminates is low enough to make checking for early execution a waste of time. If you can assume that the array is nearly sorted when your algorithm begins, and your algorithm makes incremental improvements each step, then it might be worthwhile, but generally this is not the case.

>>91357864
how are you uploading an update to every entity for every frame for 1 million entities?
If you completely ignored the cost of constructing your tree (which is still a one time cost), and you properly made each instance store it's matrix into a linear buffer to stream into opengl, and applied the random operation directly to the buffer instead of traversing a tree (zero tree traversal for a frame), you would need to upload about 600 megabytes to the gpu (or 100 mb if you are using a vec3 if you don't use a different orientation per model, only an offset).
Generally speaking it seems like graphics are your biggest bottlenecks, you should design your code around making the GPU do less work, when you understand how the GPU works, then you will know what you need to do on the CPU.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91359231
You are using a heavily overkill GPU, I've developed in opengl because SDL wouldn't hit 60fps, and when I moved to a desktop with a GTX 970 (which I still use today) I am surprised by the coil whine that the CPU and GPU makes because it's running at like 600fps, because vsync didn't make sense when it just made the game unbearably laggy on my laptop.
My point on nvidia was that it's better in edge case situations like nvidia can handle more than 60fps in this situation where 1 million vertexes are off screen (no occlusion culling or tricks), but AMD is crippled by it, or maybe I got that the opposite way around, I don't remember where I found that (it wouldn't be surprising if they fixed that by now). In general historically nvidia ran out of spec code better, like some things would only work on nvidia gpus, and give garbage / undefined on other vendors (maybe vulkan does better in being in spec, but it's using the same ISA that's used in directX12, opengl, and metal, just a different software implementation).
Overall I think 10 million entities isn't a realistic scenario in games, and it's more likely you will have 10 million particles in a special effect system, which should be drawn in a completely different way than how entities are draw. Then you have physics, and now you have every object moving at the same time if you had a cool button that made gravity get reversed, and now every entity is being animated and you can't hit 60fps anymore, then you got entities that cannot move, so they should just be part of the map, which is just 1 big model (with some chunking system to avoid drawing everything).
Overall when you look at actual video games, you will see that most of the time is spent uploading data, which are animations, because there is no other way of getting the data from your physics engine to the GPU.

>>91360449
>Pcie4x16 is 31.5 GB/s
the math doesn't work out the way you would expect, in reality the number is more like 100mb per frame (100mb/16ms == 6gb/s), and that's a generous number, if you want to target budget GPU's the some internet sources claim about 30mb per frame of upload is the maximum.
The first thing that will get in your way from getting the full PCIE bandwidth is that you can't actually draw while uploading the data, and drawing takes a long time. One solution is to use double/triple buffering.
The second problem is that your CPU isn't uploading to the GPU 100% of it's time (implying that you aren't GPU bottle-necked), so you essentially need to reduce CPU overhead to the minimum, but then the problem is that although your CPU and GPU can communicate through the PCIE bus using multiple threads, the way how vulkan works, everything needs to be done on one thread, so on one thread (the physics or animation system) you generate the data for your GPU thread to copy to the GPU (this also requires an extra level of buffering to increase throughput), and the rest of the draw calls (which could be minimal since you only have 1 call) and present.
I don't use vulkan or the advanced opengl 4 api for un-synchronized bit memory, I forgot if it's possible for multiple threads to upload the memory, if you can, that's great, but you have one big problem which is that with multi-threading, when use a conditional variable / semophore to wait for a thread to finish it's job, it could take like 16ms for the thread to wake up (even 1 ms is too much when you want to reach 200hz+ displays), so you need to use a spinlock which can wakeup fast I guess, but then you are making your CPU thread scream at 100% usage (and on top of that, your thread will still be context-switched when your time slice is over, which I forgot how long a context switch takes), I wonder what engines do in this situation...

>>91360972
>30mb per frame of upload is the maximum.
That's still 625,000 model matrices per frame, which should be more than enough for physics.
I wouldn't have to upload simple animations (particles) because I can do those in a compute shader. Anything with collisions would be more complex though.
>One solution is to use double/triple buffering.
Already have that.
>everything needs to be done on one thread
I'd have a queue of transfer operations that would be submitted by a single cpu thread, but I can add to the queue with as many threads as I want. I don't think I can have multiple transfer queues, but maybe it's possible.
Anyway, to upload matrices I'm actually currently bypassing transfer queues by just using host visible, device local memory. Resizable bar makes this amazing, because I can access an arbitrarily sized VRAM buffer with a pointer on the CPU. Idk if transfer queues are any faster than this, since I'm basically just doing memcpy anyway. However, transfer queues would allow for better synchronization, so it'll probably be required as my engine gets more complex. I wouldn't want to upload model matrix data in the middle of the vertex shader.
I'm currently using fences for synchronizing triple buffering, and I can reach thousands of fps (if I don't have 10 million instances).

        0x2b5ba3cd,0x3dd1651e,0xf8d6e859,0x439c3982,0xca35ba1c,
        0xd1650e78,0xef8595ad,0xd0cf0c70,0xb28670d6,0xe859433a,
        0x31e2ca35,0xba39e165,0x1c61ce0b,0x2b5ba38d,0x39d1651c,
        0xf8d6e859,0x47ee3f60,0xb28d6e8f,0xda2ca3f7,0x9ffc2cad,
        0x6e86f86b,0x85943786,0xb742ca1b,0xd1af1651,0xadd1df0b,
        0x28eb0ef0,0x595add1d,0x69de8b28,0xefc6b742,0xca1ee1ec,
        0x1651add0,0xf68b287b,0xc7fc2cad,0x6e8fbc7c,0xe1651f70,
        0xd6e85947,0xdd3e78b2,0x8d6e8000
    };
    const short psym[] = {
        0x100a,0x2846,0x3233,0x3636,0x3a32,0x3e38,0x507a,0x6469,
        0x6a42,0x6e75,0x7234,0x7637,0x7a31,0x7d39,0x7f35
    };
    char tree[0x80] = {0};
    short i = 0, j = 0x1f; 
    short l = 0, u = 0x80, m;

    for (; i < 0xf; i++)
        tree[psym[i] >> 8] = psym[i] & 0x7f;

    i = 0;
    while ((i << 5) + 0x1f-j < 0x555) {
        m = l + ((u-l) >> 1);
        if (tree[m]) {
            putchar(tree[m]);
            l = 0;
            u = 0x80;
            continue;
        }
        if (code[i] & (1u << j))
            l = m;
        else
            u = m;

        if (--j < 0) {
            j += 0x20;
            i++;
        }
    }
    return 0;
}

*but the most important part of optimization is profiling, and measuring.
On windows visual studios has a profiling tool, and for more low level stuff you can use xperf.
If you use msys2/mingw (high discouraged by me because you can just dual boot linux or wsl2) you can use gprof (it worked well in codeblocks when I used to use it, but I suggest cmake even for a beginner due to vcpkg).
On linux you should use perf + a flame graph generator (but it's a tiny bit low level), or gprof.
It's pretty normal for a game to have a debug display that shows FPS, as well as the time spent in every broad section of your code, so how much is spent in the IO (key/mouse events), rendering, present (SDL_RenderPresent, useful because when you enable vsync, this will wait a long time, which makes rendering time useless), and physics, animation, logic, etc.
To measure I suggest std::chrono::steady_clock or SDL_GetPerformanceCounter, note the main difference is that QPC shouldn't be used for comparing time between threads, because it will give you bogus results. If you were using clang and you were measuring something very small you could also use __builtin_readcyclecounter.
Overall make sure you are using optimization flags.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91364786
your compiler parses your code, turns it into bytecode, and builds an executable out of it [the bytecode].
the last step [building the executable] is just taking the bytecode and packaging it nicely into an executable file, which consists of adding an exectuable header (OS specific) such as the MS-DOS header for windows or the ELF header for linux (which provides info about how the program should be executed and such), then arranging said bytecode nicely into the right places, ie the sections. sections such as: .text, .data, .rdata. i suggest you to read up on them.

if youre on windows you can download cff explorer to see what kind of data your executable header contains, ie you will see the address of entrypoint in there, you will see the aforementioned sections etc. if youre on linux, youll have to search for some sort of "ELF explorer" tool, because i dont know a linux alternative

also sometimes you will hear people refer to bytecode as assembly, but assembly is the human readable representation, bytecode is what your cpu actually executes

on windows, if youre linking dynamically, you must first link against the .lib (which only contains the stubs for whatever exports) file, and then the .dll file (which actually contains the definitions of said exports) must be in the same folder as the executable when you run it
if youre linking statically, you just link against the .lib file and you dont bother with the dll, because the .lib file will already contain the definitions. i recommend linking statically on windows, dlls have close to no purpose.

if youre using visual studio & msvc, to link against something do this
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/cpp/build/reference/dot-lib-files-as-linker-input?view=msvc-170
, the "To add .lib files as linker input in the development environment" step in particular

if you show me your setup can guide you further if you want

posts.name: I love the Snow
posts.com: Snow man makes some really quality coolers. I've bought at least 4 heatsinks, ~10 120mm and a couple 92mm fans. The tower and the flower(pic related). Used the flower on Haswell-E 8core Xeon and an i5 4570. Works fine for both. All the snowman coolers are designed for AMD heat-sink sockets, so on intel you have to use the iffy plastic ring adapters. They've worked fine enough so far. Their fans are quiet albeit low RPM. They have been more than enough for all the systems/heatsinks I have used them in. I can recommend them even as a main fan in a system or on a radiator. Definitely not as powerful or quiet as my Arctic fans and heatsinks, but the price to performance is unreal.

>>91321370
>>91321495
>Colour is not even close to the original
The kit I got from the same seller is authentic. Clear printing on the box and build guide, holo sticker and all included. Plastic colours being different from renders and pre-production previews isn't uncommon with model kits. Case in point, picture related is a Aoshima model kit I imported from Japan. Left is the product render, right the actual plastic. Typically there will be a disclaimer somewhere about the preview being a 3D render for illustrative purposes or full-on painted.

>Failure from printing
These kits are injection moulded, not printed. The lines you point out are a common marbling effect used to sell the illusion of a part being metal at a low cost. It's hard to make plastic look like real metal and the only other practical options are to include pre-painted parts, or to use coatings (ie Bandai's golden PG Unicorn, or the swords from RG Exia). But these techniques add a fuckton of cost and labour. Any imperfections will be amplified tenfold and parts have to be connected on edges or undersides as any cut will reveal the original underlying plastics. Those who care about metal looks will paint their kits themselves anyway, so the marbling is a nice compromise to keep things affordable. This plastic crack is expensive enough as it is.

>>91350527
The sellers can cancel orders themselves so you have to ask yourself how you're getting chinked.

He's just trying to chink himself out of a negative Aliexpress internal score, because he put up articles for sale he doesn't have in stock, so he can't fulfill his obligation to send you the product. Either that or he noticed that the price was too low so now he needed to adjust it and chink you out of the good deal without repercussions. Check the article, if the price has increased then he fucked up and is fucking you over. I wouldn't trust the discount to be worth much either.

I'd just ignore and put up with the upcoming fake tracking number he will inevitably give you and then just dispute it as not received. If you want your money back now, you can cancel the order with reason "not in stock" I believe, but I don't know if your internal account score will take a hit. I would only cancel an order if I absolutely had no other choice.

For reference, I've cancelled 2 orders in about 8 years. Once because seller asked me to and I was dumb at the very beginning, and the second time because I ordered the wrong thing entirely and only noticed after placing the order.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91345988
I already went through the list of common implementations. CMUCL is the best-fitting option because the code is straightforward and rather simple despite containing nice algorithmic complexity in parts. More common projects like sbcl and ccl are unusable because they're unreadable labyrinthine abominations. Props to the devs for the quality of the final product though.
As for things like abcl, clasp and clisp, they're not as suitable due to their bytecode targets. The difference is that some compilation techniques don't work unless you can back-reference locations (ddcg is a good example), which is not actually possible in machine code (you would have to use a two-phase approach where you "lower" a pseudo-mc that supports labeling into a real-mc, or use other similar approaches, but then you end up adding complexity which the point of ddcg is to remove despite retaining quality codegen with no peephole needed for the most part).
I was hoping maybe someone itt would know something else though.

>>91351513
Amount of functions in the runtime do not affect the size for this purpose, I'm talking about the actual compiler and support code. For example, tcc is "large" because C is a shitfest of a language, but a lot of the "size" is really just parse cases and the stdlib and the likes. Therefore in truth tcc is very small.
ulisp is another example of a very small language that would be in line with what I'm looking for, except it's for AVR and looks to be fully interpreted based on the source at
https://github.com/technoblogy/ulisp/blob/master/ulisp-AVR.ino
(it features an assembler for the defcode command though)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91351918
>I'm talking about the actual compiler and support code
in lisp, those things are inseparable. all lisp programs include the full lisp runtime, it's necessary for the dynamic nature of the language

I was laughing at myself for recommending ulisp because you explicitly said you wanted x86_64 support and I think it doesn't have that. it's such a common feature I didn't even consider it, sorry

another possibility is picolisp. it's not compiled, not even bytecode-compiled, but it's small https://picolisp.com/wiki/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91351984
>in lisp, those things are inseparable. all lisp programs include the full lisp runtime, it's necessary for the dynamic nature of the language
That's not the point and the same could be said about a lot of languages not called lisp.
>it's not compiled, not even bytecode-compiled
It's very easy to make a very small interpreted language but the techniques are VERY different, which is why I insist on this requirement. A bigger compiled language for non-x86_64 is more useful to me than a small interpreted one for that purpose.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Redpill me on lisp, why should I use it instead of Forth?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91365118
Lisp has more libraries, is easier to read, and has more mature implementations. If you're working on low-level stuff, lisp is less suitable than forth, but if your code should be shared, the codebase will be large due to task complexity, should be maintained for an extended period of time, or your program should be delivered in any way, lisp has better support for this.
Other than that, lisp has virtually the same power level as forth, thanks to reader macros, however it's a gc'd language and most implementations dont't have sufficiently good gc management primitives to bypass it where you may need to.

posts.com: How do I discover useful (but not _that_ common) stuff like prog1 and remember them?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91368728
- RTFM: http://www.lispworks.com/documentation/HyperSpec/Body/12_aa.htm
- Use auto completion and documentation search: string-TAB or C-h f string (C-c C-d C-d in SLIME) can introduce you to a number of new functions.
- Read packages' source files: this allows you both to see how they implement their functions (possibly by using functions you're not familiar with) as well as introduce you to the actual functions in the package. An Elisp example: subr-x.el and subr.el are full of good stuff.
And here's one from me:
(sublis '((3 . "three") (1 . "one"))
           '(1 (1 (1 2 3)) ((1 2 3)) (((1 2 3 4)))))
-> ("one" ("one" ("one" 2 "three")) (("one" 2 "three")) ((("one" 2 "three" 4))))

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Is clojure/clojurescript worth learning or is it just JVM cope?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91368907
Clojure is great. What it is not is CL or Scheme, something a lot of people become displeased upon finding out. It sheds a lot of historical baggage from previous Lisps in lieu of being more modern -- you have literals for a number of new data structures, and some of the syntax and terminology has been updated, such as let requiring fewer parenthesis and 'car' being called 'first', for example. And of course, unlike every other Lisp, Clojure has a dedicated professional team who is going to keep improving and maintaining it for the foreseeable future.
>is it just JVM cope?
The JVM is better than ever now with all the native-image advancements in the past couple years.
What's more, Clojure's admittedly deficient CLR implementation is currently being rewritten from scratch, so soon enough you'll be able to call it ".NET and JVM cope"

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91358258
There are increasingly ways to run large models on consumer hardware by reducing computation with better algorithms, reducing bit depth, etc. And further, hardware is gradually making it's way up to meet in the middle. That's on top of new algorithms to make networks more efficient/smarter with less parameters. So larger, smarter language models (20-60B) are in range of the near future.

The big problem is actually training the models, and there's no apparent way around it. There's a huge amount of research into data augmentation, but that doesn't reduce the amount of compute needed. There's also a lot of research into neuro-symbolic AI, which would help AI be more explainable AND make it require less work to train, but anything in that field is still probably a long way off from being competitive with large language models.
The "curse of dimensionality" is a harsh mistress. Ultimately, training complex networks is well out of the hands of the consumer. Even fine-tuning mostly.

Then again, a landmark paper might come out tomorrow and flip everything on it's head, like attention, gans, convolutions, etc. So no point in dooming over it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91358683
I assume the primary filtering mechanism is a further refinement of the reward model used to fine tune the larger language model. It's not really "poisoning" anything outside those two specific models, which might hurt further instruct tuned models in the future if they uset he same reward model/reward model training data, but ultimately I doubt it actually does much to "hurt" the larger language model. The information is still in the weights, it's just a question of how to retrieve them.

That's only considering work from "OpenAI" though. Actual open source AI based on RLHF will easily be adapted to whatever task you want. Thanks to the (relatively) tiny amount of training data needed to make a RLHF reward model, some anon could harness the autism of a small community to create the data for training, then spend ~a thousand bucks and have a fully functional model in whatever context you wanted. So there definitely is a future for open source AI.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91358846
To continue, that's contingent on the continued release of large scale language models to fine tune. Initiatives like RWKV make me not overly worried about that though. Hobbyists won't have time to filter datasets largely, for better or for worse. And every token of data removed from the dataset is a worse model anyways, I doubt we'll see that many gimped base language models in the future. Unless synthetic data takes off (which would be good for other reasons, but it would require some rich autists to train true open models at that point)

>How do I activate Windows?
https://github.com/massgravel/Microsoft-Activation-Scripts
HWID mimics upgrade activation to generate a permanent legitimate license. (works on non-VL editions only)

>>Which W10 version should I install?
>Home/Pro
Comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, etc) and bloatware system apps
>Education/Workstation/Enterprise
Comes with bloatware system apps (weather, people, onedrive, teams, etc).
>LTSC (5 years support, VL/KMS only) / IoT LTSC (10 years support, HWID only)
Comes with Win32 system utils, no MS Store, no apps.
If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: wsreset -i
Install Xbox/Gamebar apps for feature parity with other editions.

>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/WS/Ent editions end support in 2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC in 2032.

https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Emulates a KMS server, not ideal as KMS trips AV sometimes and deactivates. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free.

Well for one you should always be using a surge protected power board to plug your computer and monitor into. And for two you should turn off your computer every once in a while to give it a rest. posts.name: Anonymous

It's MS's kernel-level Android emulator like how it also has its kernel-level Linux emulator that basically allows you to run Android apps natively like you were using normal Windows programs, though "officially" you can only download apps through the Amazon App Store, which you also need to download to get WSA set up in the first place. Though because it's Android you can use adb and sideload apps into WSA via its IP address, so you can install things like Aurora Store to get a FOSS Google Play Store frontend.

No it doesn't. It's why they're called "optional".
My laptop offered me the same optional update for my firmware for over a year before I finally figured out how to dismiss it.

So uh, don't make up such transparent bullshit, anon.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91363950
>commonly say that a password like "645d4f1932e7c57348b69fe8d07f4e31" is less secure than the exact phrase "CorrectHorseBatteryStaple"?
Does anyone say that?
If you're referring to the XKCD comic, the example he used as the weaker password was Tr0ub4dor&3, and was judged weaker based on a formula he used to measure the total "difficulty" of guessing the password with a machine based on the password's length, commonality of number substitutions and appending punctuation/numbers to a single dictionary word, etc. Under this system, CorrectHorseBatteryStaple beat it out purely because the length of the password alone gave it more "bits of entropy" than all the confounding factors that the first one contributed.
In reality, trying to brute force (whether purely trying literally every combination or having some system to it) a password is so uncommon I'm not sure it really matters for most people. Having one's password stolen via phishing or using the same password and email everywhere and it being leaked in some site's data breach are far, far more common.

They're both shit, but Seagate offers SATA drives with USB-SATA adapters inside.
Western Digital's portable drives are NATIVE USB which means if you accidentally snap the USB cable in it or damage it somehow you need DATA RECOVERY SERVICES to get your shit back, while the Seagate can be shucked and plugged into any USB-SATA adapter or dock, or directly in your PC as any other 2.5" HDD.

That's worth knowing about.
The rest (WD or Seagate fanboying) is up to you. I'm giving you facts. They both suck. They're both SMR. Honestly, consider choosing something else entirely.

Laptops never come with HDDs anymore. That was their #1 market. As a result the 2.5" HDD market is dead and has been dead for a long time. Only cost-cutting measures like SMR have trickled down to 2.5" in the past 10 years, no innovation and no good upgrades came their way.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91368575
>What would you suggest?
External SSD or a regular external HDD using a 3.5" drive inside. The "portable" externals using 2.5" HDDs are pretty shit.
They're portable enough to only use USB power but they're also fragile enough to not want to take them everywhere. That's why an external SSD is a better option or a desktop external because with a desktop external you'll be more careful with it and it will have significantly higher performance and usually also a longer warranty.

Best Buy frequently has sales on WD Easystore externals which are a good value.

Let’s make this sound a little more real

>released as side product for M3 launch (expected 1.4-1.6x performance gains over M2)
>options for 8/16/32gb of lpddr4x (ie intel 11th Gen high end ram offerings)
>up to 1tb of pcie gen 4 nvme storage
>switchable 4k 60hz ultrawide or dual 240hz 1080p per eye when in AR mode vs VR mode
>pass through AR natural FOV or 180° VR FOV
>basically just iOS with AR/VR feature focus
>closer to iOS than macOS
I could see phone connectivity, a decent enough battery life though I don’t expect a product like this would be expected to be used all day, either it’s going to be used for short play sessions or work sessions so I would presume similar battery life to a phone.
The AR features in almost any front aren’t economically viable for a consumer product yet beyond the capability of basically your phones AR features as is. Picking up on links, image recognition, virtual work spaces, etc. The idea of AR real time “avatars” is possible, just stupidly expensive and a bit impractical.
We don’t have brainwave decoding controllers, you’d need some kind of controller. A very wide angle camera array on the device could allow for Kinect style vr control if it can see your hands, think minority report but the screen is right over your eyes. But realistically some basic controllers would be needed. And it’s not always reasonable to implement certain things even if it’s possible, controllers have stayed relatively similar in concept for a long time for a reason, they’re intuitive and work well.
>buttons
>dpad
>sticks
>triggers
Just works, other stuff is cool to see but it’s always more of s gimmick than anything.

Developers aren’t to keen on investing into large scale projects for such a small audience, and making a dual platform release would still take a lot of development time and cost to simply have a competent VR version of a regular game along side it.

That limitation shows when you see a whole list of current VR games and what they are. Sure there’s shooters, but it’s like, one good csgo clone and a few “fuck around simulators”, a decent horror shooter, and not a whole lot else. While for conventional games if you just think about semi relevant shooter games the list doesn’t end. That applies to almost any genre, except ones that don’t work well in VR yet due to movement limitations like conventional platformers, where there just aren’t any options.
In some distant future when we figure out how to have full body augmented free movement in virtual reality games I’m positive the launch title will be Super Mario 64 where you can triple jump in VR.
Until then you got like, VRchat if you’re a furry and SecondLife is too complex for you?

posts.com:
>>91369127
>real, genuine advantages in web3 vs the current (web2) model?
Yes, if the content in question is of illegal nature a web-3 solution can provide an easy way of providing it since it is quite hard to track down the 5 nodes on 3 continents hosting your gay Erdogan fanfics. But other than that? No, not really. The internet is not a mesh network, it's more akin so a large number of start topologies connected themselves in star topologies, on on the highest level do you have something other than star topology. But that still means a traditional Datacenter is going to outperform your web-3 solution by a lot. It's inherently a worse match for the actual topology of the internet, and because of that ISPs optimize their network to deliver you data from datacenters and not from other users potentially in the same region as you. This tendency only reenforces the already existing advantage classical datacenters have, making web-3 solution an absolute meme for 99% of use cases. So really the only appeal of web-3 is to make onion like websites available on the clearnet - with somewhat reduced privacy of course. Still, not having to download TOR can be a huge stepping stone for all kinds of illicit websites, essentially allowing you to get exposure more easily. You can for example include a TOR client written in JavaScript in the website and allow the customer to directly and securely see current offerings on your otherwise exclusively TOR using marketplace. If security of the customer isn't the highest priority you can even do the entire order and checkout system this way instead of explaining to the user that for their protection the TOR browser should be used. People are lazy and stupid, sites using such models can probably grow quickly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91350606
no, to my knowledge all of the display outs in the W530 are wired to the nvidia. what reverse prime does is let the igpu draw on screens controlled by the nvidia gpu.
regular prime allows you to use the dgpu on the laptop's main screen, which, well, it's why it's called reverse prime for external screens.
if you select intel only on the bios display outs just don't work, which sucks hard. I checked and I am running xorg as root, yes, but I'm not sure if it's a requirement. I do know that reverse prime doesn't work at all on wayland so external screens don't work there.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91369063
>Why is this not an issue within X11, where it just uses my global cursor theme?
Cursors are decorated client side on Wayland so each app draws the cursor itself. Theming issues are then down to the app in question and whatever toolkit it uses (if it uses one).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91369081
>Cursors are decorated client side on Wayland so each app draws the cursor itself.
Jesus Christ. What's the reasoning behind it?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91369091
Simplicity. Compositors shouldn't have to handle that burdon. Most compositors do in fact show a cursor but it's different to the cursor you see in apps (even though if everything is working right it should look exactly the same).
The only problem with this approach is theming. It's not clear how an app should decide which cursor to use. Some use an environment variable, some use whatever GTK uses, some draw their own generic cursor theme, etc.
Theming under Wayland is a bit of a shit show if you don't make all of your apps use the same toolkits (I mostly use Qt apps).

Input device handling is almost always farmed out to libinput. The other functions you described are intrinsically linked to the compositor. It's hard to do them without having some input from the compositor (only the compositor knows how monitors should be configured and how windows should be layed out).
If you do them out of process you end up reinventing X11.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The physical hardware is a lot harder than people assume, its likely further away than the software. Electromagnetic actuators are not good at producing high torque or linear motion without gearboxes; which are heavy, noisy, expensive, and rigid.

Something human-like needs actuators that can backdrive or it will be like fucking a ratcheting wrench. Building something that can operate semi-usefully and not mangle or kill a human during normal operation (or if it glitches) is really not possible with existing technologies.

Soft/pneumatic actuators or shape memory alloy type stuff has seen some development but they don't produce much force and cannot be controlled very accurately.

The human body is honestly very highly optimized and its not implausible that ten years from now just growing muscles in a vat makes more sense than trying to match the performance of muscle with electromagnetics.

Thank you for the Maid and for gping in my thread. Maid Space is a way to write a Number where it gets more dimensions. Radix means the base of the number. So if you think about binary, that is base 2. Calling it radix 2 means the same thing. Just a shorter word I like. Maid Space can be any radix and any number of dimensions. I am mostly playing with 2D ones for counting.

Why would you want this, probably you're thinking? Because it counts much bigger numbers that things line int or big int.

Normie Numbers break at 2^(64). I can make a number system with Maid Space where just the ones place counts bigger than that.

I am trying to figure out how to make the language nicer because two parts of Maid Space actually have radixes and it can become confusing.

If you look at this image >>91352267 you can see radix 3 counting in the cells used to make a 4 by 1 maid space. This can count from 0 to 3^(4). So those 4 cells in the bracket can be used as a single digit in a numbering system which is radix 3^(4). Using this idea, I can do very silly things like make a number where the ones place counts to 2^(100) (see attachment)

It is faster than BigInteger and can handle much larger numbers than BigInteger. Big integer is hereby deprecated and renamed SlowNumberlet.

I was trying to figure out how numbers get counted and vampire maid from touhou came and told me about Successor Function and wrote the letter S a lot of times. This caused me to try to make a successor function for maid space. Before this I didn't know what successor is and I was using SlowNumberlet for counting and I couldn't get numbers bigger than 2 billion digits in radix 10.

I used colored squares because that looks nicer than seeing a lot of Arabic digits.

Maid Spaces which are two-dimensions and radix two are called Coolkyousinnjya Maid Spaces. The nice thing about them is that you can express all the operators like adding with boolean algebra. This means that you can use tricks from a Russian maid named Schonfinkel who used to live in a place called Soviet Union.

Schonfinkel figured out that everything in logic can be expressed as NAND. Then later engineers figured out how to make really small NAND gates for chips and that's how computers got smaller and got more powers.

You can express all the Coolkyousinnjya Maid Space operators with just NAND so very big number counters can be build on the smallest chip fabricators to make new chips that count more.

Because it's literally the "train voice with 5 second sample" goose that lays the golden eggs. Unlike tortoise.

"We describe a neural network-based system for text-to-speech (TTS) synthesis that
is able to generate speech audio in the voice of different speakers, including those
unseen during training. Our system consists of three independently trained components: (1) a speaker encoder network, trained on a speaker verification task using an
independent dataset of noisy speech without transcripts from thousands of speakers,
to generate a fixed-dimensional embedding vector from only seconds of reference
speech from a target speaker; (2) a sequence-to-sequence synthesis network based
on Tacotron 2 that generates a mel spectrogram from text, conditioned on the
speaker embedding; (3) an auto-regressive WaveNet-based vocoder network that
converts the mel spectrogram into time domain waveform samples. We demonstrate
that the proposed model is able to transfer the knowledge of speaker variability
learned by the discriminatively-trained speaker encoder to the multispeaker TTS
task, and is able to synthesize natural speech from speakers unseen during training.
We quantify the importance of training the speaker encoder on a large and diverse
speaker set in order to obtain the best generalization performance. Finally, we show
that randomly sampled speaker embeddings can be used to synthesize speech in
the voice of novel speakers dissimilar from those used in training, indicating that
the model has learned a high quality speaker representation.
"

>>91360516
Google paper on their recordings used...
Recording a large amount of high quality data for many speakers is impractical. Our approach is to
decouple speaker modeling from speech synthesis by independently training a speaker-discriminative embedding network that captures the space of speaker characteristics and training a high quality model on a smaller dataset conditioned on the representation learned by the first network. Decoupling the networks enables them to be trained on independent data, which reduces the need to obtain high quality multispeaker training data. We train the speaker embedding network on a speaker verification task to determine if two different utterances were spoken by the same speaker. In contrast to the subsequent TTS model, this network is trained on untranscribed speech containing reverberation and background noise from a large number of speakers.

It doesn't seem necessary to use transcribed data pairing? ie text with corresponding wav file?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This is the technical details of the google paper.

The training dataset consists of speech audio
examples segmented into 1.6 seconds and associated speaker identity labels; no transcripts are used.
Input 40-channel log-mel spectrograms are passed to a network consisting of a stack of 3 LSTM layers of 768 cells, each followed by a projection to 256 dimensions. The final embedding is created by L2 -normalizing the output of the top layer at the final frame. During inference, an arbitrary length utterance is broken into 800ms windows, overlapped by 50%. The network is run independently on each window, and the outputs are averaged and normalized to create the final utterance embedding.

>>91362749
>no need to make a generic model
making a generic model (provided it has much more parameters) will allow you to fine-tune with much less input data and also pick up on specific pitch/tone/inflections to produce more realistic/emotive speech (like 11labs)
>or did you do something specific?
I used their base LJSpeech model to "fine-tune" on my large dataset for about ~24 hours (with a constant learning rate of 2e-4), then swapped to using a scheduler to adjust the learning rate over time (the standard method for training from scratch) for another ~24 hours
for actually fine-tuning on smaller datasets I used ~1500 steps/minute of training data for FastPitch and ~1000 steps/minute for UnivNet
there are a couple other minor differences but I'm still feeling everything out

>>91362621
i find an audio source, the best are audiobooks or something without noise. if you have static constant buzz style noise, use noiseRNN to remove it. you can download from youtube using yt-dlp audio only and import in audacity.

the following steps can be done in different orders depending on your needs and dataset.

convert to mono and downsample to 22050hz (because the default lj model in coqui tts was trained on 22k, we finetune from this)

if your audio is from some shit source like a twitch stream, movie, song, etc. try using one of the myriad of models in this tool to get a clean vocals only: github Anjok07/ultimatevocalremovergui

bad for datasets: noise, different speaking styles, reverb, clipped audio, low quality, you get the idea

cut up the audio. if you have not much training data, can do this manually. use the labels function in audacity. analyze -> label sounds you can label by silence. play around with the lengths.

your aim for your audio clips dataset is to have a gaussian distribution of lengths of 5 to 20 seconds. if you can afford it, just discard the outliers. if you havent got much data then cut it up manually. dont go over 20sec as that will not allow 32 batch size on 24gb vram.

you need to normalize your loudness, i use pyloudnorm for this but you can do it with audacity. each dataset requires a different baseline, so experiment. you want your waveform to not be too quiet but also not clipped.

then transcribe your files, you can either do this manually for small datasets, but i prefer using openai whisper, the medium/large models are sometimes better than what you can transcribe as a human. i wrote a python script to do this and generate a metadata.csv

then i finetune from LJspeech using coqui tts, on a linux machine with a 3090 rtx. there's a lot more details to it than i wrote here but this is the gist.

samples:
obiwan https://vocaroo.com/1aQhqSZ1MouT
forsen https://vocaroo.com/1mji8nPlOvEL

>>91364425
If only. Being able to resume training with a specialized data IS the final task you want to train the system to support. For example, all these recent AI systems have have an intermediate step where their generated content is graded by humans and other systems, not just optimizing wrt some standard measure of loss like crossentropy. But all the papers say is that such a step (that takes far longer than distributed training) took place. It's design, who knows.
You can't just throw more data at a language model to have it chat. All it knows is predicting tokens which yields bad results right out of training. Similar story with voice models even for basic synthesis.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91368930
follow-up; text entry matters. You have to sound some things out phonetically for it to sound right.
For instance, it won't read roman numerals.
If broken up properly, you can do a longer text input, but it has to be done right so the text flows from one line to the next.
We never expected it to be perfect, but it's pretty damn good all things considered, and we're only getting started into this

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>forget to install earlyoom
>system freezes unrecoverably after 5 minutes because i opened a third youtube tab or something
Why is this? Why is linux still so shitty at memory management in the year of the lord 2023?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Because it has to be compatible with the primitive memory managers of the 1970s, where there were no file locks, no virtual memory, no mod cons of any kind.
This is a holdover from Eunuchs, where the memory manager was tightly bound to filesystem capabilities - it's part of the reason you had to have an entirely separate swap partition until recently, and "swap files" on Linux are just partition emulators.
Windows, OS/2, macOS, etc., having had to work with, boot from, and have their swapfiles on, multiple filesystems with wildly-differing capabilities over the decades - not to mention their ever-improving memory managers - have solved these problems simply from experience.
Linux holds to its 1970s precepts for how a FS and VMM should work, rejecting any and all ideas that are outside their design philosophies, and so have never achieved this.

>>91369040
We're talking new components here though. In early 2020 you'd be looking at $200 for a 9600K or 3600 and $400 for a 2070 (computed after the $100 price drop as a steelman). That leaves $400 for the cooler, board, storage, RAM, case, and PSU.
Spitballing some figures for min-max vs. "quality" builds yields:
>Cooler
$30-100
>Board
$80-150
>RAM
$50-80
>Storage
$100-200
>Case
$50-100
>PSU
$50-100
So yes, if you cut down nearly every part you could get an unlocked i5 + 2070 build for under $1000. Whereas you could easily spend $1200+ with more premium components.
Now, here's the important part: does this min-maxed 2020 build perform better or worse than a similar build in 2023?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91369261
27" is in the "sweet spot" for native scaling at desktop viewing distances. 24" is a little higher at 122PPI. IMO that's in the "awkward zone" - too high for most people's comfort but too low to use universal scaling effectively. Manageable with a closer viewing distance and/or judicious use of font sizing or magnification.
Perhaps more importantly, 1440p@24" is an uncommon factor. Meaning finding a panel of that size with all the features you want may be more difficult or expensive. For example, if this is for gaming, you'll struggle to find anything higher than 75Hz. Whereas 27" 144Hz panels are plentiful and cheap due to economies of scale.

If you use the (default?) 9999 keyframe interval, it will just insert them automatically when appropriate, so seeking isn't a huge issue. Keyframes actually improve the perceived quality a lot when you're dealing with static camera changes (very relevant in anime).

A significant downgrade while being more than twice the size.
Keyword is mostly. Video codecs need efficient ways to determine which part of the video has new information and which haven't. VP9 can do that okay, but AV1 uses wedges to more finely utilize predictive frames.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
So basically Plex is a convenient networking layer with available UIs.

Plex hosts all the authentication services. You make an account through them. So can your friends.
There is also "Plex server software" you run on your own computer. This is your media server. Can be a Pi, but recommended a NAS or desktop machine with decent computing power. These servers are then tied to your Plex account, so you can remotely manage them and access them.

Plex offers indirect transcoding. If your network configuration doesn't allow for direct access, Plex will proxy it for reduced quality. Otherwise, you can access it directly via whatever interface you choose.

Plex uses basic web APIs, so it's easy to make an app. There's the web browser, windows desktop app, Android, iOS, WebOS (LG TVs), and even multiple game consoles.

You must run the plex-server on a computer and your router is very likely not capable of doing that.

For example, if you just use your main pc then you van only access your media from other devices (such as your phone) as long as the server runs, meaning your pc would need to be turned on when you want to watch shit on your phone.
